elements.label: Digital Dependency in Africa
elements.description: Systemic reliance on foreign-owned digital infrastructure, platforms, and data governance systems that limit African control and autonomy.

elements.label: Foreign Tech Companies
elements.description: Companies like Google, Meta, and Huawei that dominate infrastructure, platforms, and data processing in Africa.

elements.label: African Governments
elements.description: Policy makers and regulators who mediate tech partnerships, pass laws, and balance development goals with dependency risks.

elements.label: Donor Institutions
elements.description: Entities like the World Bank and USAID that fund digital infrastructure but often set the rules of engagement through conditionality.

elements.label: Local Startups & Developers
elements.description: Tech innovators and entrepreneurs building localized solutions, often facing barriers like limited funding or infrastructure access.

elements.label: Civil Society & NGOs
elements.description: Digital rights advocates, watchdogs, and grassroots groups working for inclusion, fairness, and accountability in digital systems.

elements.label: Citizens
elements.description: General public ‚Äî especially youth, women, and low-income communities ‚Äî affected by tech policies and infrastructure gaps.

elements.label: Infrastructure Ownership
elements.description: Who controls the digital backbone ‚Äî undersea cables, telecom networks, cloud systems ‚Äî matters for sovereignty and autonomy.

elements.label: Policy Influence
elements.description: National tech policies shaped by external actors via advice, alignment, and conditions tied to funding.

elements.label: Data Ownership & Control
elements.description: Control over African data ‚Äî where it's stored, who owns it, who profits ‚Äî is often outside African jurisdictions.

elements.label: Funding Flows
elements.description: External donors and investors influence what gets built, where, and how, shaping tech priorities.
